snippet: The triumph of Jermaine Paul gave “The Voice” a surprisingly affecting outcome after the show had become something of a cynic’s preserve.
abstract: Jon Caramanica analyzes the second season of NBC's singing competition show The Voice, which was won by Jermaine Paul. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: At the outset of the second season of ''The Voice'' Jermaine Paul was all about business. In his initial blind audition, he sang Avril Lavigne's bratty ''Complicated'' with muscle and imagination, if not total grace. Two of the show's four coaches turned their chairs to face him: Cee Lo Green, a whimsical eccentric who's attracted to idiosyncratic vocal powerhouses, and Blake Shelton, a gentle soul who often appears to be guided by emotion and gut more than talent. After some theatrical hemming and hawing, Mr. Paul chose Mr. Shelton, and it seemed, at the time, to be a strategic decision. On Mr. Green's team Mr. Paul would be one of several heavyweights, but surely Mr. Paul could power his way through Mr. Shelton's collection of feel-good stories.

headline.main: Tearful Underdog Triumphs In 'The Voice' Finale
